title: 108_hr3526
content:
The Act may be cited as the "David 'Davy' Crockett Commemorative Coin Act". The Congress finds that in 1830, Representative David Crockett courageously opposed a bill to fund the removal of Southeastern Native American tribes to the west of the Mississippi River, despite knowing it went against the majority of his constituents' wishes. He stood firm against political threats, refusing to support the removal of "the poor remnants of a once powerful people." The year 2005 marks the 50th anniversary of a feature-length motion picture that portrayed David Crockett as the classic image of the American frontier and the embodiment of the frontier spirit. Crockett, popularized as "Davy" Crockett in movies and television, became a cultural icon of the 1950s, representing a new, proud, and irreverent American character unique from European customs. As a young man from East Tennessee, he stood against the removal of Native American tribes despite political threats. David Crockett, a young man from East Tennessee, mastered frontier skills like marksmanship and hunting. His first rifle is part of the East Tennessee Historical Society's collection. Known for his wit and leadership, he served in the Tennessee General Assembly and the United States House of Representatives. In his final months, he fought for Texas independence. David Crockett, a hero of the Republic of Texas, died at the Alamo at 49. His life was chronicled through various mediums, solidifying his status as an American folk hero. Crockett opposed the Indian removal bill, guided by his famous maxim: "Be always sure you are right." David Crockett, a hero of the Republic of Texas, died at the Alamo at 49. His life was chronicled through various mediums, solidifying his status as an American folk hero. Crockett opposed the Indian removal bill, guided by his best-known maxim: "Be always sure you are right, then go ahead." SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint $5 gold coins and $1 silver coins in honor of David Crockett. The $5 coins will weigh 8.359 grams, have a diameter of 0.850 inches, and contain 90% gold. The $1 coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver. These coins will be legal tender. All coins minted under this Act will be considered numismatic items for purposes of section 5136 of title 31, United States Code. SEC. 4. DESIGN OF COINS. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the legacy of David Crockett and his significance to Tennessee, Texas, and the United States. Each coin will feature the coin's value, the year "2005", and inscriptions including "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", "E Pluribus Unum", and "David 'Davy' Crockett 1786-1836". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and the Board of the East Tennessee Historical Society. The design of the coins minted under this Act will symbolize the legacy of David Crockett and will be reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a single United States Mint facility. The Secretary is authorized to issue these coins only between January 1, 2005, and December 31, 2005. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS.

The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount.

SEC. 7. SURCHARGES. All sales of coins minted under this Act include a surcharge: $35 per $5 coin and $10 per $1 coin. Surcharges received will be paid to the East Tennessee Historical Society for capital improvements and endowment. The Society will be audited as per requirements. The Foundation will be audited according to section 5134(f)(2) of title 31, United States Code, for the amounts received under subsection (b).
